column2: But the fat man was very fat, and the fat woman was very fat, and the donkey man was very old, and William was young and very fleet, so in less than ten minutes they gave up the pursuit and returned panting and quarrelling to the road.
column3: But the fat man was very fat, and the fat woman was very fat, and the donkey man was very old, and William was young and very fleet, so in less than ten minutes they gave up the pursuit and returned panting and quarrelling to the road.

column2: William sat on the further outskirts of the wood and panted.
column3: William sat on the further outskirts of the wood and panted.

column2: He felt on the whole exhilarated by the adventure.
column3: He felt on the whole exhilarated by the adventure.

column2: It was quite a suitable adventure for his last day of unregeneration.
column3: It was quite a suitable adventure for his last day of unregeneration.

column2: But he felt also in need of bodily sustenance, so he purchased a bun and a bottle of lemonade at a neighbouring shop and sat by the roadside to recover.

column2: There were no signs of his pursuers.
column3: There were no signs of his pursuers.

column2: He felt reluctant to return home.
column3: He felt reluctant to return home.

column2: It is always well to follow a morning's absence from school by an afternoon's absence from school.
column3: It is always well to follow a morning's absence from school by an afternoon's absence from school.

column2: A return in the afternoon is ignominious and humiliating.
column3: A return in the afternoon is ignominious and humiliating.

column2: William wandered round the neighbourhood experiencing all the thrill of the outlaw.
column3: William wandered round the neighbourhood experiencing all the thrill of the outlaw.

column2: William decided that all things considered it was best to make a day of it.

column2: He spent part of the afternoon in throwing stones at a scarecrow.

column2: Followed--an exciting chase by an angry farmer.
column3: Followed-an exciting chase by an angry farmer.

column2: It was after tea-time when he returned home, walking with careless bravado as of a criminal who has drunk of crime to its very depth and flaunts it before the world.

column2: He could see the gardener smiling in the distance.

column3: There was a small blue bruise on his shining head.

column2: William judged from the smile that he had laid his formal complaint before authority.

column2: William noticed that his father looked pale and harassed.

column2: William crept round to the back of the house beneath the bushes.

column2: He felt that the time had come to give himself up to justice, but he wanted, as the popular saying is, to be sure of "getting his money's worth." There was the tin half full of green paint in the tool shed. He'd had his eye on it for some time.

column2: He went quietly round to the tool shed.

column3: Soon he was contemplating with a satisfied smile a green and enraged cat and a green and enraged hen.

column2: Then, bracing himself for the effort, he delivered himself up to justice.

column2: Dusk was falling.
column3: Dusk was falling.

column2: William gazed pensively from his bedroom window.
column3: William gazed pensively from his bedroom window.

column2: He was reviewing his day.
column3: He was reviewing his day.

column2: He had almost forgotten the stormy and decidedly unpleasant scene with his father.
column3: He had almost forgotten the stormy and decidedly unpleasant scene with his father.

column2: Mr. Brown's rhetoric had been rather lost on William, because its pearls of sarcasm had been so far above his head.

column2: And William had not been really loth to retire at once to bed.

column2: After all, it had been a very tiring day.
column3: After all, it had been a very tiring day.

column2: Now his thoughts were going over some of its most exquisite moments--the moments when the pea and the gardener's head met and rebounded with such satisfactory force; the moment when he swung along the high road, monarch of a caravan and a mule and the whole wide world; the moment when the scarecrow hunched up and collapsed so realistically; the cat covered with green paint....
column3: Now his thoughts were going over some of its most exquisite moments-the moments when the pea and the gardener's head met and rebounded with such satisfactory force; the moment when he swung along the high road, monarch of a caravan and a mule and the whole wide world; the moment when the scarecrow hunched up and collapsed so realistically; the cat covered with green paint....

column2: After all it was his last day.
column3: After all it was his last day.

column2: He saw himself from to-morrow onward leading a quiet and blameless life, walking sedately to school, working at high pressure in school, doing his homework conscientiously in the evening, being exquisitely polite to his family and instructors--and the vision failed utterly to attract.
